{
  "article_text": [
    "the catenoid is the only non - planar rotational minimal surface in euclidean space and it is generated by the catenary @xmath1 when rotates around the @xmath2 axis . consider a piece of a catenoid bounded by two coaxial circles @xmath3 with the same radius @xmath4 and separated a distance @xmath5 far apart .",
    "it is known that if we go separating @xmath6 from @xmath7 , there is a critical distance between @xmath6 and @xmath7 where the catenoid breaks into two circular disks around each circle @xmath8 .",
    "the relation between @xmath9 and @xmath10 is the following : there exists a value @xmath11 such that if @xmath12 , there are exactly two catenoids connecting @xmath6 and @xmath7 , if @xmath13 , there is exactly one and if @xmath14 , there is no a catenoid spanning @xmath3 ( see for example @xcite ) .",
    "related with the above phenomenon , there is the question to determine if a catenoid is a minimizer of surface area because in general , one of the two catenoids is not a absolute minimizer .",
    "exactly , there exists a value @xmath15 such that if if @xmath16 , then there exists a unique catenoid spanning @xmath3 that is an absolute minimum for the surface area but if @xmath17 , then the two disks spanning @xmath8 give an absolute minimum for surface area ( the so - called goldschmidt discontinuous solution ) .",
    "notice that if @xmath18 , then the catenoid is only a local minimum .",
    "in this paper we consider in @xmath0-dimensional lorentz - minkowski space @xmath19 the problem on the number of catenoids connecting two coaxial circles . in this setting , we need to precise the above notions .",
    "first , it is the definition of a rotational surface . in @xmath19",
    "there are three types of uniparametric groups of rotations depending on the causal character of the rotation axis and are called _ elliptic _ , _ hyperbolic _ and _ parabolic",
    "_ when the rotation axis is timelike , spacelike and lightlike respectively .",
    "in particular , in @xmath19 there are three types of rotational surfaces .",
    "we call a _ circle _ of @xmath19 the orbit of a point under some of the above groups of rotations when such as an orbit is not a straight line . on the other hand , the notion of the mean curvature is defined in a surface whose induced metric from @xmath19 is not degenerate , that is , when the surface is spacelike ( riemannian metric ) and the surface is timelike ( lorentzian metric )",
    "catenoid _ is a non - degenerate rotational surface with zero mean curvature everywhere .",
    "the problem that we study is the following :    _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ given two coaxial circles in lorentz - minkowski space , how many catenoids span both circles ?",
    "_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _    by two coaxial circles we mean two circles placed in different planes and that are invariant by the same group of rotations .    for understanding our main result ( theorem [ t - main ] )",
    "we need to point out some observations . if two circles are coaxial , then they are invariant by one of the three groups of rotations , but not for the other two ones ( see sect .",
    "[ sec2 ] for the description of the circles in @xmath19 ) . on the other hand ,",
    "the causal character of the circles imposes restrictions on the ( possible ) catenoid that span .",
    "for example , if the two circles are timelike curves , then the catenoid can not be spacelike .",
    "we will prove in some cases that the number of catenoids connecting the circles is @xmath20 or @xmath21 .",
    "in this situation we will assume coaxial circles with arbitrary radius .",
    "however , in other cases there exist many catenoids connecting two coaxial circles and this number increases as the separation distance increases ( timelike elliptic catenoids and spacelike hyperbolic catenoids of type ii ; see sect .",
    "[ sec2 ] below ) .",
    "then we suppose here that the circles have the same radius .    in the following sections",
    ", we will state in a precise manner the results obtained according to the type of the rotation group and the causal character of the surface ( spacelike or timelike ) : see theorems [ t - elliptic ] , [ t - elliptic2 ] , [ t - hyperbolic ] , [ t - hyperbolic2 ] and [ t - parabolic ] .",
    "we can now give a general view of the results in the next theorem and the corresponding table [ table1 ] .",
    "[ t - main ] let @xmath6 and @xmath7 be two coaxial circles in lorentz - minkowski space @xmath19 .    1 .",
    "there exists @xmath20 or @xmath21 catenoid connecting @xmath6 and @xmath7 in the following cases : spacelike elliptic catenoid , timelike hyperbolic catenoid of type ii and parabolic catenoid .",
    "2 .   there exist @xmath20 , @xmath21 or @xmath22 timelike hyperbolic catenoids of type i. 3 .   for timelike elliptic catenoids and spacelike hyperbolic catenoids of type ii , and if the circles have the same radius , there exists a number @xmath23 of catenoids connecting @xmath6 and @xmath7 depending on the distance @xmath10 between the circles , where @xmath24 is non decreasing on @xmath10 and @xmath25 .",
    ".the number of catenoids connecting two coaxial circles according to the type of rotation group and the type of causality of the surface . in ( * ) , the radius of the circles coincide [ cols=\"<,^,^,^,^ \" , ]",
    "we consider two coaxial circles @xmath3 with respect to the axis @xmath26 .",
    "the analysis of how many catenoids connect @xmath6 with @xmath7 distinguishes two cases according to the causal character of the surface .      after a translation and a homothety",
    ", we suppose that @xmath6 is the circle of radius @xmath21 in the @xmath27-plane .",
    "let @xmath28 and @xmath29 be the intersection points between @xmath6 and @xmath7 with the @xmath30-plane , respectively . because the profile curve of the spacelike elliptic catenoid is given in terms of the @xmath31 function , and @xmath32 belongs to the surface , then the profile curve is @xmath33 after a change of coordinates , the problem is formulated in terms of planar curves in the @xmath27-plane as follows : given a point @xmath34 , among the curves in the family @xmath35 passing through the point @xmath36 , how many of such curves does the point @xmath37 contain ? here @xmath38 ( to be distinct of @xmath39 ) and @xmath40 because @xmath37 does not belong to the rotation axis , namely , the @xmath41-axis .",
    "define the region @xmath42 given by @xmath43 and let @xmath44 be the symmetry of @xmath45 with respect to @xmath46-axis .",
    "then all the curves of @xmath47 are contained in the region @xmath48 .",
    "on the other hand , by the symmetry of the problem and the graphics of the elements of @xmath47 , the point @xmath37 must belong to @xmath49 , where @xmath50 is the symmetry of the @xmath27-plane with respect to the @xmath41-axis . as a conclusion",
    ", the point @xmath37 can not belong to @xmath51 , proving that there is not a catenoid connecting @xmath6 and @xmath7 .",
    "this gives a part of the statement of theorem [ t - main ] .",
    "suppose now that @xmath52 .",
    "since the circle generated by the point @xmath53 is the same one than @xmath37 , it is sufficient to consider the case of @xmath54 and we are looking for an element of @xmath47 of type @xmath55 with @xmath56 . under this assumption on the point @xmath37 , we will prove that there is exactly one curve of @xmath47 going through @xmath37 .",

    "a simple study of the function @xmath84 proves that @xmath72 , @xmath85 in a neighborhood of @xmath86 of @xmath87 and when @xmath88 , the function @xmath10 has exactly a local maximum @xmath89 and a local minimum @xmath90 , where @xmath89 and @xmath90 are determined by @xmath91 the value @xmath10 at @xmath89 is @xmath92 because @xmath93 .",

    "we have proved :    [ t - elliptic ] let @xmath3 be two euclidean coaxial circles in @xmath19 with respect to the @xmath2-axis .",
    "then the number of spacelike elliptic catenoids spanning @xmath3 is @xmath20 or @xmath21 .",
    "a zero mean curvature spacelike surface is called a maximal surface because it maximizes the area .",
    "in fact , by the expression of the jacobi operator associated to the second variation of the surface area , it is straightforward to check that the surface is stable in a strong sense , that is , the first eigenvalue of the jacobi operator on any compact domain is positive @xcite .",
    "for this reason , and in contrast to the euclidean setting described in the introduction , it was expected that there would be a unique catenoid at most connecting two coaxial circles .",
    "we analyse the case of two coaxial circles with the same radius .",
    "although this case is covered in theorem [ t - elliptic ] , in this particular case we find a relation between the radius and the separation between the circles .",
    "[ c1 ] let @xmath95 be two circles of radius @xmath4 with respect to the @xmath2-axis and separated a distance @xmath96 far apart .",
    "then the number of spacelike elliptic catenoids connecting the circles @xmath97 is @xmath20 if @xmath98 and it is @xmath21 if @xmath99 .",
    "we formulate the problem for planar curves in the @xmath27-plane .",
    "let us fix the point @xmath100 and study how many curves of type @xmath101 go through the point @xmath37 .",
    "this is equivalent to study the number of solutions of equation @xmath102 where @xmath9 is a given number and the unknown is @xmath68 .",
    "define the function @xmath103 .",
    "we have @xmath104 and @xmath105 .",
    "since @xmath106 and the numerator is always positive , the function @xmath67 is strictly increasing , proving that there is a unique value @xmath68 reaching @xmath107 only for @xmath99 .",

    "we summarize the above results .",
    "[ t - elliptic2 ] let @xmath127 and @xmath188 be two coaxial euclidean circles of radius @xmath4 with respect to the @xmath2-axis and separated a distance equal to @xmath189 . if @xmath24 denotes the number of timelike elliptic catenoids connecting @xmath127 and @xmath128 , then :    1 .",
    "@xmath24 is a finite number .",
    "2 .   @xmath24 is a non - decreasing function on @xmath10 .",
    "the limit of @xmath24 is @xmath190 as @xmath191 .",
    "there exists @xmath192 such that if @xmath193 , then @xmath194 .    by the above proof",
    ", we have the next information about the number of catenoids connecting@xmath127 and @xmath128 :    1 .   1 .",
    "if @xmath195 , then there is not a catenoid .",
    "2 .   if @xmath196 , then there is not a catenoid .",
    "2 .   1 .   if @xmath197 , then the number of catenoids is @xmath20 , and if @xmath198 , then it is @xmath21 .",
    "if @xmath199 , then there is no a catenoid .    using the inequality @xmath200 , we obtain that if @xmath201 , the number of catenoids is more than 1 and we can take at least two catenoids which correspond to the cases ( 1,a ) and ( 2,a ) .",
    "we see that the behavior of the number of timelike elliptic catenoids connecting two coaxial circles with the same radius is the opposite to the euclidean case : as we increase the separation between the circles , the number of catenoids connecting them increases .",

    "in this section , we consider two coaxial hyperbola @xmath3 and we ask how many of hyperbolic catenoids connect @xmath6 with @xmath7 . using the same terminology of proposition [ p - revolution ] , we say that @xmath3 are two coaxial hyperbolas of type i ( resp .",
    "type ii ) if there exists a hyperbolic rotational surface of type i ( resp .",
    "type ii ) connecting @xmath6 with @xmath7 .",
    "in particular , @xmath6 and @xmath7 are timelike hyperbolas ( resp .",
    "spacelike hyperbolas ) .",
    "the profile curves are given in theorem [ t - rot ] .",
    "exactly , the profile curve of the hyperbolic catenoid of type i is @xmath206 , @xmath207 , @xmath208 , which coincides with the catenary in the euclidean setting and whose behavior has been described in the introduction for coaxial circles with the same radius .",
    "when the surface is of type ii , the profile curves have appeared in the elliptic case .",
    "thus we have :    [ t - hyperbolic ] let @xmath3 be two coaxial timelike hyperbolas in @xmath19 with respect to the @xmath41-axis .",
    "then the number of timelike hyperbolic catenoids of type i spanning @xmath3 is @xmath20 , @xmath21 or @xmath22 .",
    "the statement of this theorem needs to be clarified in the following sense . in euclidean space , and for @xmath56 , @xmath208 ,",
    "the two catenoids obtained by rotating about the @xmath2-axis the curve @xmath209 and the profile curve @xmath210 coincide because the circles of the catenoid are euclidean circles .",
    "however in @xmath19 , for timelike hyperbolic catenoids of type i , the corresponding catenoids are different .",
    "exactly , the catenoids @xmath211 @xmath212 are separated by the plane @xmath213 of equation @xmath214 , with @xmath215 and @xmath216 . therefore , in theorem [ t - hyperbolic ] we are assuming that the coaxial circles @xmath3 lie in the same side of the plane @xmath213 . for example , taking @xmath217 , @xmath218 , the timelike hyperbolas of type i given by @xmath219 and @xmath220 , @xmath5 , are separated a distance @xmath96 .",
    "although they are invariant by the group of rotations whose axis is @xmath221 , they can not be connected by a hyperbolic catenoid of type i _ for every value @xmath10_. therefore if we want to state a similar result as in euclidean space relating the distance between the hyperbolas and the existence of a catenoid connecting them , we have to add the assumption that they lie in the same side of @xmath213 .",
    "thus we have :    let @xmath222 be two coaxial timelike hyperbolas of radius @xmath4 and separated @xmath96 far apart .",
    "then there is a number @xmath11 such that the number of timelike hyperbolic catenoids of type i connecting @xmath97 is @xmath20 , @xmath21 or @xmath22 depending if @xmath14 , @xmath13 and @xmath223 , respectively",
    ".     and @xmath224 far apart ( blue ) connecting by two profile curves @xmath225 for values @xmath226 and @xmath227 ( red ) .",
    "right : the corresponding two hyperbolic catenoids of type i , title=\"fig : \" ]   and @xmath224 far apart ( blue ) connecting by two profile curves @xmath225 for values @xmath226 and @xmath227 ( red ) . right : the corresponding two hyperbolic catenoids of type i , title=\"fig : \" ]    we now consider two coaxial spacelike hyperbolas of type ii .",
    "similarly to the case of theorem [ t - hyperbolic ] , there exist spacelike hyperbolas of type ii that can not be connected by a timelike hyperbolic catenoid of type ii . for example",
    ", this occurs with the hyperbolas @xmath228 and @xmath229 which are in the same side of the plane @xmath230 of equation @xmath231 . for the case of spacelike hyperbolic catenoids of type ii , this phenomenon does not occur because the profile curve is given in terms of the sine function",
    "therefore , in ( 1 ) of theorem [ t - hyperbolic2 ] below , we are assuming that the circles lie in opposite sides of @xmath230 .",
    "[ t - hyperbolic2 ]",

    "consider a parabolic catenoid in @xmath19 . by theorem [ t - rot ] , we know that the profile curve of a spacelike surface is @xmath235 ( @xmath56 ) , and if it is timelike , then @xmath236 ( @xmath56 ) .",
    "the surface has a singularity when it meets with the rotation axis , that is , when @xmath237 .",
    "1 .   spacelike case .",
    "the generating curve is @xmath235 with @xmath56 .",
    "the formulation of the problem for planar curves is as follows . given two points @xmath37 and @xmath39 of the @xmath27-plane , find how many curves of type @xmath238 , @xmath56 , pass through @xmath37 and @xmath39 .",
    "the rotation axis of the surface corresponds with the @xmath46-axis . after a vertical translation and a homothethy",
    ", we suppose that @xmath239 .",
    "then @xmath240 . let @xmath241 be another point of the @xmath27-plane .",
    "the problem reduces to find how many curves of the family @xmath242 go through the point @xmath39 . by the graphics of the elements of @xmath47 ,",
    "a first necessary condition is that @xmath39 must belong to the region @xmath243 , where @xmath244 in particular , if @xmath245 , there is not a spacelike parabolic catenoid connecting both circles .",
    "this proves the part of theorem [ t - parabolic ] that asserts that the number of catenoids connecting two circles is @xmath20 .",
    "suppose now that @xmath246 .",
    "we will find a value @xmath68 such that @xmath247 and next , study how many values @xmath68 satisfy this equation .",
    "the function @xmath248 satisfies @xmath249 and @xmath250 . since @xmath251",
    ", a continuity argument proves that there exists a value @xmath68 such that @xmath66 . on the other hand ,",
    "the derivative @xmath252 is positive , proving that @xmath67 is strictly increasing , so the uniqueness of the curve among all ones of the family @xmath47 .",
    "it follows the existence of a unique catenoid connecting the corresponding two circles .",
    "the argument when @xmath253 is similar .",
    "this finishes the proof of theorem [ t - parabolic ] for a spacelike surface .",
    "2 .   timelike case .",
    "the generating curve is @xmath235 with @xmath254 .",
    "again , we suppose that @xmath239 so @xmath240 . let @xmath241 be another point of the @xmath27-plane .",
    "the same argument as above proves that if @xmath39 belongs to the region @xmath255 , where @xmath256 there exists a unique curve going through @xmath39 and if @xmath257 , then there is not a such curve .",

  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in @xmath0-dimensional lorentz - minkowski space we determine the number of catenoids connecting two coaxial circles in parallel planes . </S>",
    "<S> this study is separated according to the types of circles and the causal character ( spacelike and timelike ) of the catenoid . </S>"
  ]
}
